articles.headline: Peloton Is a Phenomenon. Can It Last?
articles.snippet: Exercise manias like the Thighmaster and Tae Bo have all come and gone. Peloton is trying to defy that trend.
articles.abstract: Exercise manias like the Thighmaster and Tae Bo have all come and gone. Peloton is trying to defy that trend.
articles.lead_paragraph: As far as indoor cycling machines go, the $2,245 Peloton bike is nothing special. It has a sleek black and red frame. It has a big screen. It’s on Wi-Fi.

articles.headline: Wang Guodong, Who Painted Mao Year After Year, Dies at 88
articles.snippet: He received one of China’s highest — and most intimidating — honors: responsibility for creating the huge portrait that gazes down on Tiananmen Square.
articles.abstract: He received one of China’s highest — and most intimidating — honors: responsibility for creating the huge portrait that gazes down on Tiananmen Square.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — His portraits were among the most recognizable in the world, rivaling the Mona Lisa.

articles.headline: Japan and South Korea Feud, but Breaking Up Is Hard
articles.snippet: Tokyo put new trade limits on Seoul and South Korean shoppers are spurning Japanese goods, but the ties between the two U.S. allies may be hard to unwind.
articles.abstract: Tokyo put new trade limits on Seoul and South Korean shoppers are spurning Japanese goods, but the ties between the two U.S. allies may be hard to unwind.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — As tensions between Tokyo and Seoul have surged in recent months, South Koreans have shown their anger with their wallets. Japanese beer is going unsold. Shoppers are avoiding Uniqlo. An animated Japanese children’s movie called “Butt Detective,” whose protagonist has a predictably posterior-shaped head, bombed in South Korean theaters.
articles.byline: By Su-Hyun Lee and Ben Dooley

articles.headline: While Wall St. Talks of Recession, Bond Investors Make a Killing
articles.snippet: You should have bought bonds. They’re doing great.
articles.abstract: You should have bought bonds. They’re doing great.
articles.lead_paragraph: For stock investors, the trade war has been nothing but trouble. For bond investors, it’s been a dream.

articles.headline: New Government Takes Shape in Italy, Sidelining Salvini and the Hard Right
articles.snippet: The turnabout in Italy’s politics was as a relief to the European establishment. But the new coalition may prove no more stable, or less conflict-ridden, than the one it replaces.
articles.abstract: The turnabout in Italy’s politics was as a relief to the European establishment. But the new coalition may prove no more stable, or less conflict-ridden, than the one it replaces.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s warring political parties struck a deal late Wednesday to form a new government that shunted aside Matteo Salvini, the hard-right leader who dominated the country’s politics for more than a year and threatened to drastically reorient Italy’s place in Europe.

articles.headline: Democratic Candidates Jostle, and Gripe, as Debates Winnow the Field
articles.snippet: A set of qualifying rules created a few final hours of uncertainty over who would qualify and whether the next debate would be held on one night or two. There was plenty of complaining.
articles.abstract: A set of qualifying rules created a few final hours of uncertainty over who would qualify and whether the next debate would be held on one night or two. There was plenty of complaining.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The suspense was high. The hour was late. The questions about the next Democratic debate were many: Ten candidates or 11? Two nights or one? One billionaire or none?

articles.headline: The Israel-Iran Shadow War Escalates and Breaks Into the Open
articles.snippet: Israel believes Iran is trying to equip its Arab allies with high-tech weapons that could overwhelm Israel’s defenses. It has been taking action to stop it.
articles.abstract: Israel believes Iran is trying to equip its Arab allies with high-tech weapons that could overwhelm Israel’s defenses. It has been taking action to stop it.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel has carried out a series of attacks across the Middle East in recent weeks to prevent Iran from equipping its Arab allies with precision-guided missiles, drones and other sophisticated weapons that could challenge Israel’s defenses.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger, Ben Hubbard and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: A Windswept Plain, a Sea of Oil and a Mountain of Money
articles.snippet: A Chevron-led joint venture among several energy companies is spending billions of dollars in Kazakhstan to expand an oil field remarkable for its longevity, promise and risk.
articles.abstract: A Chevron-led joint venture among several energy companies is spending billions of dollars in Kazakhstan to expand an oil field remarkable for its longevity, promise and risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: TENGIZ OIL FIELD, Kazakhstan — In a windswept land of salt flats and wild horses, investors are pouring money into one of the largest and most lucrative oil fields outside the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Nanna Heitmann

articles.headline: Why Aren’t More Women Working? They’re Caring for Parents
articles.snippet: The needs of older relatives remove women from the labor force in the United States far more than in other wealthy nations, at a cost to the economy.
articles.abstract: The needs of older relatives remove women from the labor force in the United States far more than in other wealthy nations, at a cost to the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUNWOODY, Ga. — Aisha Adkins would rather have her own place, instead of living with her parents. She would also like a job, a car, a master’s degree and savings. But at 35, a decade after graduating from Georgia Southern University in Statesboro with a specialty in social services, she has had to put off those goals.

articles.headline: WeWork Is Going Public. Are Its Numbers Too Private?
articles.snippet: As the fast-growing purveyor of shared work space prepares for an I.P.O., its filings lack some important insights.
articles.abstract: As the fast-growing purveyor of shared work space prepares for an I.P.O., its filings lack some important insights.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s a lot that the world’s hottest real estate company isn’t telling us as it prepares for its stock market debut.

articles.headline: Blocked in Business, South Korean Women Start Their Own
articles.snippet: Glass ceilings in a conservative country’s biggest companies have motivated a new generation of female entrepreneurs.
articles.abstract: Glass ceilings in a conservative country’s biggest companies have motivated a new generation of female entrepreneurs.
articles.lead_paragraph: HWASEONG, South Korea — At first glance, Energy Nomad appears to be a typical South Korean company: Just about everybody who works there is male.

articles.headline: Comey Is Criticized by Justice Dept. Watchdog for Violating F.B.I. Rules
articles.snippet: The department’s inspector general said the former F.B.I. director set “a dangerous example” by releasing memos about his interactions with President Trump to people outside the bureau.
articles.abstract: The department’s inspector general said the former F.B.I. director set “a dangerous example” by releasing memos about his interactions with President Trump to people outside the bureau.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The former F.B.I. director James B. Comey violated policy by disclosing memos about his interactions with President Trump to people outside the bureau, said a blistering Justice Department inspector general report released on Thursday. The report admonished him for setting “a dangerous example” for officials with access to government secrets.
